questions.text: Mrs. Patel is a 45-year-old woman who has recently been diagnosed with estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer. Her doctor informs her that the cancer is hormone-dependent. The doctor recommends a treatment plan that includes surgery, radiation therapy, and hormone therapy. What is the drug used for estrogen dependent breast cancer? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Tamoxifen

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) used to treat hormone receptor-positive breast cancers, particularly in premenopausal women. It is effective for estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer, which is hormone-dependent. Tamoxifen works by blocking the effects of estrogen in the breast tissue, thereby preventing cancer cells from growing and spreading.
  • • Mechanism of Action : Tamoxifen competes with estrogen for binding to estrogen receptors in breast tissue. By blocking estrogen's effects, it inhibits the growth and proliferation of estrogen-dependent cancer cells. Administration : Tamoxifen is taken orally, usually once a day for five years. Side Effects : Common side effects include hot flashes, mood changes, vaginal dryness, and an increased risk of blood clots (DVT).
  • • Mechanism of Action : Tamoxifen competes with estrogen for binding to estrogen receptors in breast tissue. By blocking estrogen's effects, it inhibits the growth and proliferation of estrogen-dependent cancer cells.

  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Estrogen: Estrogen is not used as a treatment for estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer because it would promote cancer cell growth. In fact, therapies aim to reduce or block estrogen to prevent cancer progression.
  • • Option A. Estrogen:
  • • Option B. Clomiphene citrate: Clomiphene citrate is a medication used to induce ovulation in women with fertility issues. It is not used in the treatment of breast cancer.
  • • Option B. Clomiphene citrate:
  • • Option D. Adriamycin (Doxorubicin): Adriamycin is a chemotherapy drug used to treat various types of cancer, including breast cancer. It works by interfering with the DNA in cancer cells, preventing them from dividing and growing. While effective in some cancer treatments, it is not specifically used for hormone therapy in estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following is the usual cause of thyroid storm in thyroidectomy? (AIIMS NOV 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: Rough handling of thyroid during surgery

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Inadequate patient preparation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A thyroid storm, also known as thyrotoxic crisis, is a rare but life-threatening medical emergency that occurs in individuals with severe hyperthyroidism. Hyperthyroidism is a condition in which the thyroid gland produces an excessive amount of thyroid hormones, primarily thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3). In a thyroid storm, these hormone levels become dangerously elevated, leading to a wide range of symptoms and complications.
  • ➤ Symptoms of a thyroid storm may include:
  • ➤ High fever Rapid and irregular heartbeat (tachycardia) Elevated blood pressure Extreme agitation and restlessness Profuse sweating Tremors and shaking Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea Delirium or confusion Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes) Coma (in severe cases)
  • ➤ High fever
  • ➤ Rapid and irregular heartbeat (tachycardia)
  • ➤ Elevated blood pressure
  • ➤ Extreme agitation and restlessness
  • ➤ Profuse sweating
  • ➤ Tremors and shaking
  • ➤ Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea
  • ➤ Delirium or confusion
  • ➤ Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes)
  • ➤ Coma (in severe cases)
  • ➤ Thyroid storms can be triggered by various factors, such as surgery, infection, trauma, or medication changes in individuals with underlying hyperthyroidism. The condition is more common in people with Graves' disease, a common cause of hyperthyroidism.
  • ➤ Treatment of a thyroid storm is a medical emergency and typically involves a combination of interventions to rapidly lower thyroid hormone levels, control symptoms, and support vital organ function.
  • ➤ The usual cause of thyroid storm in thyroidectomy is inadequate patient preparation before surgery. Thus, patient preparation pre-operatively involves ensuring a euthyroid state.

questions.text: Sequence of color change in Raynaud’s disease:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) White - Blue - Red

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Raynaud’s disease, also known as Raynaud’s phenomenon, is characterized by a triphasic color change in the digits, typically triggered by cold exposure or emotional stress. The sequence of color change follows these stages:
  • • White (Stage of Local Syncope) : Initially, exposure to cold or stress causes digital arterioles to spasm, reducing blood flow. This leads to blanching or pallor in the affected digits. Blue (Stage of Local Asphyxia) : As the spasm persists, capillaries and venules dilate in response to ischemic metabolites, resulting in cyanosis or a bluish discoloration due to deoxygenated blood. Red (Stage of Recovery) : Upon rewarming or resolution of the vasospasm, there is a sudden increase in blood flow through the dilated arteries and capillaries, causing reactive hyperemia and a bright red color in the digits.
  • • White (Stage of Local Syncope) : Initially, exposure to cold or stress causes digital arterioles to spasm, reducing blood flow. This leads to blanching or pallor in the affected digits.
  • • White (Stage of Local Syncope)
  • • Blue (Stage of Local Asphyxia) : As the spasm persists, capillaries and venules dilate in response to ischemic metabolites, resulting in cyanosis or a bluish discoloration due to deoxygenated blood.
  • • Blue (Stage of Local Asphyxia)
  • • Red (Stage of Recovery) : Upon rewarming or resolution of the vasospasm, there is a sudden increase in blood flow through the dilated arteries and capillaries, causing reactive hyperemia and a bright red color in the digits.
  • • Red (Stage of Recovery)

  • • Option B. Red - Blue - White : Incorrect sequence; does not represent Raynaud's color change pattern.
  • • Option B. Red - Blue - White
  • • Option C. White - Red - Blue : Incorrect sequence; does not represent Raynaud's color change pattern.
  • • Option C. White - Red - Blue

  • • Option D. Red - White - Blue

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The sequence of color change in Raynaud’s disease is White (pallor) - Blue (cyanosis) - Red (hyperemia).

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • King's College Criteria are widely used to predict mortality in patients with acute liver failure and identify those who may require urgent liver transplantation.
  • • Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy: According to the King's College Criteria for non-paracetamol causes, a duration of jaundice before the onset of encephalopathy greater than 7 days (not less than 7 days) is one of the parameters that might indicate the need for liver transplantation. If the encephalopathy develops rapidly after the onset of jaundice (i.e., within 7 days), it suggests a more acute and potentially reversible cause, such as acute viral hepatitis, which might recover without transplantation.
  • • Given the information, the incorrect parameter in the King's College criteria for transplantation, would be "Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy" (Option D).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Age <10 years: Age is a factor in the King's College Criteria for non-paracetamol-induced liver failure. Children aged less than 10 years are considered at higher risk and this age group may be included in the criteria for transplantation.
  • • Option A.
  • • Age <10 years:
  • • Option B . PT >100s: Prothrombin time (PT) reflects the liver's ability to synthesize clotting factors. A greatly prolonged PT (>100 seconds) is an indication of severe liver dysfunction and is one of the King's College Criteria for both paracetamol and non-paracetamol-induced liver failure as a potential requirement for liver transplantation.
  • • Option B
  • • PT >100s:
  • • Option C. Bilirubin >300 mmol/L : An elevated bilirubin level indicates significant liver dysfunction. A bilirubin level greater than 300 µmol/L is one of the King's College Criteria for non-paracetamol-induced liver failure and suggests that liver transplantation may be necessary.

CT scan is the preferred diagnostic tool for retroperitoneal injuries, but it should only be performed on hemodynamically stable patients. The patient is positioned supine, and a 3.5-5.0 MHz convex transducer is used to scan the subxiphoid, right and left upper quadrants, and suprapubic region to assess potential thoracoabdominal injuries. eFAST is an extended version of FAST that incorporates left and right thoracic views to assess for pneumothorax and hemothorax.

questions.text: An octogenarian female comes to your clinic reporting feelings of constant fatigue. Upon performing imaging studies, you discover that she has a scleroatrophic gallbladder containing impacted stones. In addition, a sizable stone is detected within the common bile duct, causing dilation of the biliary tree. What should be the subsequent course of action in her treatment? (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure that allows for the visualization and management of bile duct stones. It is particularly useful when there is a stone in the common bile duct (CBD). ERCP can be used to remove or extract stones from the common bile duct and may also involve the placement of a stent to relieve biliary obstruction if necessary.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy: Cholecystectomy (removal of the gallbladder) may be considered as a subsequent procedure, but it is usually not the initial step in patients with impacted stones in the gallbladder and CBD stones. ERCP is performed first to address the CBD stone and relieve any associated biliary obstruction.
  • • Option A. Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy:
  • • Option C. Wait and watch: Waiting and watching may not be appropriate in this case because the patient is symptomatic with constant fatigue, which can be related to biliary obstruction. Immediate intervention is necessary to relieve the obstruction and prevent complications.
  • • Option C. Wait and watch:
  • • Option D. CT scan: A CT scan may have been done as part of the initial imaging studies to assess the condition, but it is not the definitive treatment for gallbladder and CBD stones. The primary treatment should focus on relieving the obstruction caused by the CBD stone.
  • • Option D. CT scan:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is the preferred initial treatment for patients with common bile duct stones and biliary obstruction, as it allows for both diagnosis and therapeutic intervention, such as stone removal and stent placement.

It has been shown to provide the highest percentage of excess weight loss compared to other bariatric procedures. BPD/DS achieves significant weight reduction by reducing the stomach size and bypassing a substantial portion of the small intestine, which limits calorie absorption. However, this procedure also has a higher risk of nutritional complications compared to other bariatric surgeries.

questions.text: Decubitus ulcer is best classified as: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Decubitus ulcer is synonymous with pressure ulcer. These terms describe tissue necrosis with ulceration resulting from prolonged pressure that exceeds capillary occlusion pressure (over 30mmHg), leading to tissue anoxia and breakdown. They occur in areas where bony prominences create sustained pressure against soft tissues, particularly in bedridden or immobile patients.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Venous ulcer - Venous ulcers have distinct characteristics, typically appearing above the medial malleolus in the "Gaiter's area." They present as shallow ulcers associated with other signs of venous insufficiency such as hyperpigmentation, dermatitis, and varicosities. Unlike decubitus ulcers, they result from venous hypertension rather than direct pressure.
  • • Option A. Venous ulcer
  • • Option B. Arterial ulcer - Arterial (ischemic) ulcers occur at distal locations like toes and dorsum of foot. They are characteristically deep, severely painful, and associated with signs of peripheral vascular disease including brittle nails, sparse hair, and intermittent claudication. They stem from inadequate arterial perfusion rather than external pressure.
  • • Option B. Arterial ulcer
  • • Option C. Neuropathic ulcer - Neuropathic ulcers typically form on weight-bearing areas of the foot with characteristic "punched out" edges and surrounding callosity. They develop due to sensory, motor, and autonomic neuropathy (commonly in diabetic patients) rather than from external pressure. The painless nature of these ulcers distinguishes them from decubitus ulcers.
  • • Option C. Neuropathic ulcer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pressure sores (decubitus ulcers) result from sustained pressure exceeding tissue perfusion pressure, causing ischemia and necrosis predominantly at bony prominences like the ischium, greater trochanter, and sacrum in immobile patients.

questions.text: A lady presents with a three-day history of epigastric pain radiating to the back. questions.explanation:

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Acute pancreatitis is characterized by epigastric pain that often radiates to the back. Although elevated serum amylase is commonly seen in acute pancreatitis, normal levels do not exclude the diagnosis. The presence of an enlarged pancreas on ultrasonography is suggestive of acute pancreatitis. Gallstones are a common cause of acute pancreatitis, and their presence in the gallbladder further supports this diagnosis. A contrast-enhanced CT scan is the definitive imaging modality for diagnosing acute pancreatitis, assessing its severity, and identifying complications.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Acute cholecystitis: While gallstones are present, the combination of pancreatic enlargement and radiating pain to the back is more indicative of acute pancreatitis than acute cholecystitis, which typically presents with right upper quadrant pain and tenderness.

  • • Option C. Acute appendicitis: This condition presents with right lower quadrant pain and is not associated with pancreatic enlargement or gallstones.

  • • C. Acute appendicitis:
  • • Option D. Acute peritonitis: Peritonitis would present with diffuse abdominal pain and tenderness, not specifically epigastric pain radiating to the back, and would not be associated with pancreatic enlargement.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Acute pancreatitis can present with normal serum amylase levels. The presence of epigastric pain radiating to the back, an enlarged pancreas on imaging, and gallstones strongly suggest acute pancreatitis.

questions.text: Mr. Seth recently underwent surgery to remove a parathyroid gland due to hyperparathyroidism. The surgeon informed the patient that one or more of the parathyroid glands may be transferred to another location during the surgery to protect them or due to their location. The parathyroid is commonly transferred to? ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Brachioradialis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The most common site for the relocation of the parathyroid gland(s) is in the forearm muscle, specifically the nondominant side brachioradialis. Transplantation to this location provides several advantages:
  • • Accessibility : The forearm location is easily accessible for potential future surgical interventions if necessary. Monitoring : This location allows for straightforward monitoring of parathyroid function using simple clinical tests. Functionality : The transplanted gland(s) will continue to produce parathyroid hormone normally, aiding in the regulation of calcium levels in the body. Ease of Removal : If there is disease recurrence after surgery, the forearm location facilitates easy removal. Typically, a total of 12 to 14 pieces are transplanted in a type of heterotopic transplant.

  • • Monitoring : This location allows for straightforward monitoring of parathyroid function using simple clinical tests.

  • • Ease of Removal : If there is disease recurrence after surgery, the forearm location facilitates easy removal.

  • • Option A. Triceps:
  • • Option B. Biceps: Biceps is also not commonly used for parathyroid transplantation because it does not offer the same ease of access and monitoring advantages as the brachioradialis.
  • • Option B. Biceps:
  • • Option C. Sartorius: Sartorius is not a preferred site for parathyroid transplantation. The forearm muscle (brachioradialis) is favored for its convenience and monitoring benefits.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The brachioradialis muscle in the forearm is the most common site for parathyroid gland relocation during surgery due to its ease of access, convenient monitoring, and straightforward removal if needed.

  • ➤ If this is not available then a non-adhesive dressing like paraffin gauze impregnated with silver sulfadiazine (SSD) cream, colloidal silver, ionic silver cream, or silver nitrate cream may be applied. Since increased resistance to SSD has recently emerged, it should be used judiciously and reserved for deep dermal, full thickness, infected, and old neglected burns.
